newsitem.title: IRAN: Iran, S.Korea to boost annual trade to $2 billion.
newsitem.headline: Iran, S.Korea to boost annual trade to $2 billion.

text.p: Iran and South Korea agreed on Wednesday to boost their annual trade to $2 billion from $1.6 billion, the Iranian news agency IRNA said.

Under a letter of understanding signed in Tehran, Iran and South Korea agreed to raise bilateral trade to $2 billion by the end of the Iranian year ending on March 20, 1997 from $1.6 billion the previous year, it said.
Iranian Vice-President Hamid Mirzadeh said South Korea would boost oil imports from Iran and expand cooperation in energy, car-making, copper production, and shipbuilding, IRNA added.
South Korea's International Trade and Industry Minister Park Jae-yoon, quoted by the daily Tehran Times, said it was possible to reach a bilateral trade target of $4 billion by 2000.
He said trade was up 50.8 percent in the nine months to September over the same period last year, the paper added.

"Despite American sanctions against Iran, South Korea is determined to expand relations with the Islamic Republic," Iranian television quoted Park as saying at the end of a meeting of the two countries' joint economic commission.
Total trade between South Korea and Iran, Seoul's third largest oil supplier, stood at $1.6 billion in 1995, of which nearly $1.3 billion were Iranian exports.
Park visited Iran to attend the first meeting of the economic commission held after a five-year lapse.
